newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovak parliament withdraws anti-subversion law.
newsitem.headline: Slovak parliament withdraws anti-subversion law.

text.p: Slovakia's ruling coalition has withdrawn plans to push through parliament a controversial law which was heavily criticised for borrowing on communist-era anti-subversion legislation.

Peter Brnak, Constitutional Committtee chairman and Movement for a Democratic Slovakia (HZDS) member, told parliament late on Thursday the move was "a result of the will of the coalition to draft better-quality legislation."
Jan Cuper, a leading HZDS deputy, told Reuters: "A new version of the law will probably be placed on the agenda of the December session of parliament."
The law was originally drafted by the ultra-right Slovak National Party (SNS) -- a junior coalition partner -- as the price for supporting a treaty with neighbouring Hungary.
The controversial penal code with "protection of the republic" legislation, was originally approved in March but later returned by President Michal Kovac for revision.
The United States and the European Union have criticised the law, an ammendment to the penal code, and other legislation drafted by the government of Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar.
Both have expressed concerns that Slovakia is dragging its feet on a commitment to democracy.

Under the law, people could be punished for acts such as organising anti-government demonstrations or publishing "false information" abroad. Some of its wording is almost identical to anti-subversion laws scrapped after the 1989 fall of communism.

The opposition proposed that the law be wiped off the agenda of the current parliament which comes up for re-election in the autumn of 1998, but the proposal was rejected by the three- party coalition which holds a majority in the legislative body.
